channel.title: NYT > World News
channel.copyright: Copyright 2023 The New York Times Company

item.title: As Ukraine Clings to Bakhmut, What’s Its Strategy and What’s at Stake?
item.description: Ukraine is determined to hold the eastern city as long as it can. How high a price is it willing to pay? What might force its withdrawal? And what would a retreat look like — and mean?
item.dc:creator: Marc Santora
item.media:description: Ukrainian soldiers from the 93rd Brigade at a position near Bakhmut on Thursday.

item.title: They Sneaked Into a Derelict Arms Plant: Instagrammers or Spies?
item.description: Three people, including two Russians, arrested on charges of entering an abandoned rifle factory have puzzled Albanian authorities at a time when suspicions about Moscow have been mounting.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: The site in Gramsh, Albania, where three interlopers were arrested in August. “I don’t think there is anything to spy on there,” the country’s prime minister said.

item.title: Nobel Prize Is No Defense Against Jail for Ales Bialiatski in Belarus
item.description: Ales Bialiatski, last year’s Nobel Peace Prize laureate, has been sentenced by Belarus to 10 years in prison, on charges that rights advocates have dismissed as politically motivated.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Ales Bialiatski, the head of Viasna, a Belarusian human rights group, center, during a court session in Minsk, Belarus, in January.

item.title: Biden and Germany’s Scholz Meet Amid Concerns Over Ukraine and China
item.description: President Biden said he and Germany’s chancellor, Olaf Scholz, would work in “lock step” to provide military support to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Katie Rogers
item.media:description: President Biden and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany are trying to show that they are the stewards of a strong NATO alliance against Russian aggression and Chinese interference.

item.title: The E.U. Offered to Embrace Ukraine, but Now What?
item.description: The European Union and NATO have promised a path to membership for the embattled country. But real partnership will hold risks and benefits for both sides.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger
item.media:credit: Emile Ducke for The New York Times
item.media:description: Walking past piles of protective sandbags in the historical Podil neighborhood of Kyiv in February.

item.title: Search of Train Crash Site in Greece Nears an End
item.description: The authorities were planning to start clearing the debris after Greece’s deadliest rail disaster, with some relatives receiving confirmation that their loved ones had died, while others had to wait.
item.dc:creator: Niki Kitsantonis
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: The crash site, near the Vale of Tempe, in northern Greece, on Friday. The collision between a passenger train and a freight train killed at least 57 people.

item.title: Rules to Curb Illicit Dollar Flows Create Unintended Hardships for Some Iraqis
item.description: The regulations were meant to prevent dollar transfers to corrupt actors. But they have ended up harming ordinary Iraqis who need U.S. currency for legitimate purposes.
item.dc:creator: Alissa J. Rubin
item.category: Federal Reserve Bank of New York
item.media:description: Waiting outside an authorized currency dealer in Baghdad to exchange Iraqi dinars for U.S. dollars.

item.title: Thai Hunger Strikers Calling for Changes to Monarchy Are at Risk of Dying
item.description: The two young women have not had food for 44 days, part of a campaign urging the government to repeal a law that criminalizes criticizing the royal family.
item.dc:creator: Sui-Lee Wee
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Protesters outside the Supreme Court in Bangkok in February. The case of two women on a hunger strike has drawn attention from demonstrators and rights workers.

item.title: China Increasingly Seen as Antagonist in Diplomatic Talks Globally
item.description: Tensions over China arise in many gatherings of global leaders and diplomats, as Beijing increasingly plays a spoiler role, often siding with Russia.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: A worker moving a Chinese national flag before the opening session of the G20 foreign ministers’ meeting in New Delhi on Thursday.

item.title: Cambodian Opposition Leader Is Found Guilty of Treason Before Election
item.description: Kem Sokha, co-founder of the defunct Cambodia National Rescue Party, was accused of conspiring to overthrow the government and sentenced to 27 years of house arrest.
item.dc:creator: Seth Mydans
item.media:description: Kem Sokha, the co-founder of the now-defunct Cambodia National Rescue Party, leaving his house for the Phnom Penh Municipal Court on Friday.

item.title: Bullying Accusations Snare K-Pop Stars and Athletes in South Korea
item.description: In South Korea, such allegations have affected the careers of public figures. The takedowns have public support, but critics wonder if some go too far.
item.dc:creator: John Yoon and Mike Ives
item.media:description: An Woo-jin, who was accused of bullying while in high school, will not play in the World Baseball Classic despite being one of the top pitchers in South Korea.

item.title: King Charles Will Travel to France and Germany for First State Visits
item.description: Britain’s new monarch and his wife, Camilla, the queen consort, will attend state banquets in Paris and Berlin later this month.
item.dc:creator: Jenny Gross
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Chris Jackson/Chris Jackson Collection, via Getty Images
item.media:description: King Charles III last month. He will make his first state visits since becoming king to France and Germany.

item.title: Why Is TikTok Being Banned?
item.description: Governments have expressed concerns that TikTok, which is owned by the Chinese company ByteDance, may endanger sensitive user data.
item.dc:creator: Sapna Maheshwari and Amanda Holpuch
item.media:description: TikTok has long denied allegations that it puts sensitive user data into the hands of the Chinese government.

item.title: Biden’s World Bank Pick Looks to Link Climate and Development Goals
item.description: Ajay Banga will begin a monthlong “global listening tour” to drum up support for his nomination to be the bank’s next president.
item.dc:creator: Alan Rappeport
item.media:description: Ajay Banga will travel the globe for support for his candidacy to be the World Bank’s next president.

item.title: U.S. Attorney General Garland Meets Zelensky in Ukraine During Surprise Visit
item.description: A major topic of talks was how to hold Russia accountable for any war crimes committed over the past year.
item.dc:creator: Glenn Thrush
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
item.media:description: Attorney General Merrick B. Garland, center, visited Lviv, Ukraine, on Friday and met a group of international prosecutors including the Ukrainian prosecutor general, Andriy Kostin, left, to discuss allegations of war crimes committed in Ukraine.

item.title: The Sordid Secrets of Cities
item.description: Machine politics, corruption and violence.
item.dc:creator: Amanda Taub
item.media:description: J. Edgar Hoover, the longtime F.B.I. director, sits at a table speaking into several microphones in 1953.

item.title: The U.S. Will Send $400 Million in New Military Aid to Ukraine
item.description: Western leaders have warned of a looming artillery shortage for Ukraine as its troops burn through thousands of shells each day in trying to push back Russian forces.
item.dc:creator: Lara Jakes and Helene Cooper
item.media:description: The United States will supply Ukraine with additional medium-range rockets for the multiple-rocket launchers known as HIMARS that it has already provided.

item.title: A New Child Care Requirement
item.description: A great idea — or a problem for semiconductor makers?
item.dc:creator: German Lopez
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Intel C.E.O. Pat Gelsinger and President Joe Biden at the site of a new Intel semiconductor manufacturing facility in New Albany, Ohio, in 2022.

item.title: The U.S. will send more ammunition to Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Erin Mendell
item.media:description: A factory producing HIMARS rocket launchers in Arkansas.

item.title: Paid Accounts on Facebook and Instagram Arrive in Australia
item.description: Users had mixed feelings about the new subscription service, which bestows exclusive features and a verification check mark.
item.dc:creator: Yan Zhuang
item.media:credit: Aaron Wojack for The New York Times
item.media:description: Meta’s campus in Menlo Park, Calif.

item.title: Germany’s Scholz Visits Washington Amid Worries Over Ukraine War
item.description: Chancellor Olaf Scholz arrives Friday for a quiet working visit with President Biden, sparking speculation that they will discuss tough questions on how to end the war.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: President Biden and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany are trying to show that they are the stewards of a strong NATO alliance against Russian aggression and Chinese interference.

item.title: The German chancellor is visiting Biden as urgency builds on Ukraine.
item.dc:creator: Erika Solomon
item.media:credit: Kenny Holston for The New York Times
item.media:description: President Biden and Chancellor Olaf Scholz of Germany meeting during a Group of 7 session in Germany in June.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing
item.description: An important exchange between Russia and the U.S.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony Blinken.

item.title: Two Kansas Men Illegally Sold Aviation Equipment to Russia, U.S. Says
item.description: The Justice Department said that the scheme had been uncovered as the United States cracked down on illegal exports to Russia since it invaded Ukraine a year ago.
item.dc:creator: April Rubin
item.media:description: The U.S. Justice Department announced the arrest of two men on charges that they illegally supplied technology to Russia.

item.title: At U.S. Base in Germany, Ukraine’s Military Conducts War Games
item.description: The exercises come as Ukraine is emerging from a winter that was expected to offer a lull in fighting. Ukraine’s president appeared to signal recently that the country is preparing for a major offensive.
item.dc:creator: Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.media:description: The supreme allied commander for Europe, Gen. Christopher G. Cavoli, in Brussels, in January.

item.title: Rail Safety Upgrade in Greece Is Hobbled by Delays and Neglect
item.description: The technology would have automatically stopped trains before they collided. Years of delays and neglect have left Greece with a hobbled system.
item.dc:creator: Monika Pronczuk and Sarah Hurtes
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: At least 57 people died when two trains collided near the city of Larissa early Wednesday.

item.title: Incursion in Russian Border Town Puts Kremlin on Emergency Footing
item.description: An armed group said it briefly took control of a border town in Russia’s Bryansk region, but what actually took place there was shrouded in conflicting claims.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev, Marc Santora and Alan Yuhas
item.media:description: A sign marking the boundary of the Bryansk region of Russia, which borders Ukraine, beside a road on Thursday.

item.title: Fire Engulfs Hong Kong Skyscraper Under Construction
item.description: The fire at the 42-story tower, which was under construction, burned for nine hours. News reports said two people were injured.
item.dc:creator: The New York Times
item.media:description: A 42-story skyscraper under construction is seen on fire in the Tsim Sha Tsui area of Hong Kong, on Friday.

item.title: Nicaragua’s Human Rights Abuses Similar to Nazi Regime, Investigators Find
item.description: A U.N. inquiry found that President Daniel Ortega and top members of his government committed human rights abuses, providing evidence for efforts to try them overseas.
item.dc:creator: Frances Robles
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: President Daniel Ortega and his wife, Vice President Rosario Murillo, in 2018.

item.title: Blinken Confronts Lavrov in First Meeting Since Ukraine War
item.description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken said he told Sergey V. Lavrov, the Russian foreign minister, that Moscow must end its war against Ukraine and return to a nuclear arms control treaty.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: Arms Control and Limitation and Disarmament
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken speaking to reporters after the G20 foreign ministers’ meeting on Thursday in New Delhi.

item.title: Your Friday Briefing: G20 Sparring Over Ukraine
item.description: Also, a suspected poisoning of schoolgirls in Iran and a crackdown on migrants in Tunisia.
item.dc:creator: Mariah Kreutter and Daniel E. Slotnik
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken at the G20 foreign ministers’ meeting in New Delhi.

item.title: Tunisia’s President Vilifies Migrants From Sub-Saharan Africa
item.description: As African migrants are swept up in a widening crackdown, critics say President Kais Saied is openly mining a deep vein of discrimination and prejudice against dark-skinned people in Tunisia.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee and Ahmed Ellali
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: Migrants from Ivory Coast outside their country’s embassy in the Tunisian capital, Tunis. Hundreds of Black foreigners in Tunisia have been swept up in arrests, rights groups say.

item.title: Hubble Telescope Faces Threat From SpaceX and Other Companies’ Satellites
item.description: Scientists found that an increasing number of pictures made by the iconic orbital observatory are being disrupted by passing satellites.
item.dc:creator: Shannon Hall
item.media:description: The scientists’ data went only through 2021, and thousands more satellites have been launched since then by SpaceX and other companies, with many more expected to go to orbit in the years ahead.

item.title: Russian Group With Ukraine Ties Say They Took Control of a Russian Village
item.description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia canceled a trip to be briefed on the incursion near the border with Ukraine. He described the incident as a “terrorist” attack.
item.dc:creator: Anatoly Kurmanaev and Marc Santora
item.media:description: A sign marking the boundary of the Bryansk region of Russia, which borders Ukraine, on Thursday.

item.title: As France Faces Backlash in Africa, Macron Tries Reset With Ex-Colonies
item.description: President Emmanuel Macron has embarked on a four-country visit as he slashes the French military presence and says colonial-era habits and attitudes must die.
item.dc:creator: Roger Cohen
item.media:description: President Emmanuel Macron of France and President Ali Bongo Ondimba of Gabon at the Presidential Palace in Libreville on Wednesday.

item.title: U.K. Spy Agency Missed Chance to Stop Manchester Bombing, Inquiry Finds
item.description: The domestic security service MI5 failed to act on intelligence about a suicide attacker before he killed 22 people at a pop concert in 2017, an investigation concluded.
item.dc:creator: Euan Ward
item.media:description: Placing flowers on the Glade of Light memorial to the victims of the 2017 Manchester Arena bombing on Thursday, after the publication of the final report on the attack.

item.title: Harry and Meghan Told to Leave Frogmore Cottage, Their U.K. Home Base
item.description: Queen Elizabeth II offered Frogmore Cottage to the couple at the time of their wedding, and it was the couple’s home base on infrequent visits to Britain.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler
item.category: Charles III, King of the United Kingdom
item.media:credit: Mike Coppola/Getty Images for 2022 Robert F. Kennedy Human Rights Ripple of Hope Gala
item.media:description: Harry and Meghan in New York in December. They currently live in Montecito, Calif.

item.title: How A.I. Can Help
item.description: ChatGPT is changing how people work. That can be scary. But for now, most jobs are still safe.
item.dc:creator: Lauren Jackson
item.media:credit: Jackie Molloy for The New York Times
item.media:description: ChatGPT

item.title: A Ukrainian Mayor Disappeared, but Questions of His Loyalty Did Not
item.description: Traitor or hero? A decision by the former mayor of Kherson to remain in his post under Russian occupation has divided opinion, even after he vanished.
item.dc:creator: Michael Schwirtz and Ivor Prickett
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: A cell at the prison where Russian forces held and interrogated prisoners during their occupation of Kherson, Ukraine.

item.title: Canadians Fume as Migrants Surge at Their Border
item.description: A surge in illegal crossings from the United States has led to calls to shut down a rural road on the Canadian border.
item.dc:creator: Norimitsu Onishi
item.media:credit: Nasuna Stuart-Ulin for The New York Times
item.media:description: Migrants from Afghanistan, Angola, Zimbabwe and other places arriving at the Roxham Road border crossing last month in Saint-Bernard-de-Lacolle, Quebec.

item.title: When Clothes Fly Off, This Intimacy Coordinator Steps In
item.description: Jessica Steinrock’s work on intimate scenes in film has come to prominence as the entertainment industry reels from the litany of sexual abuses brought to light by the #MeToo movement.
item.dc:creator: Jennifer Harlan
item.media:credit: Mary Mathis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Jessica Steinrock, the chief executive of Intimacy Directors and Coordinators, is at the vanguard of a field that facilitates the production of scenes involving nudity, simulated sex or hyper exposure.

item.title: Anger Grows in Greece After Train Crash Kills at Least 57
item.description: Interviews reveal the tragic toll on students and workers, with at least 57 people killed. Protesters angry over the rail service’s safety record clashed with the police, and train employees went on strike.
item.dc:creator: Emma Bubola and Iliana Magra
item.media:credit: Angelos Tzortzinis for The New York Times
item.media:description: Destroyed train carriages at the site of the crash near the city of Larissa, Greece, on Wednesday.

item.title: In the Ukraine war, talking about peace is a fight of its own.
item.description: Russia and the West have argued for months about which side is more willing to negotiate, with the world as an audience.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:description: U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken, right, met President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine, left, in Kyiv in September.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Natasha Frost
item.media:description: Bola Tinubu is a powerful political kingmaker in Nigeria.

item.title: Leave Russia? A Year Later Many Companies Can’t, or Won’t.
item.description: Not all Western companies packed up and left Russia after its invasion of Ukraine. Some say Moscow has tied their hands, while others choose to stay put.
item.dc:creator: Liz Alderman
item.media:description: An Auchan store in Moscow. The French supermarket chain has kept its 230 stores in Russia open.

item.title: Biden Challenged by Softening Public Support for Arming Ukraine
item.description: Proponents of more aid fear that growing taxpayer fatigue toward shipping tens of billions of dollars overseas could undercut the war effort.
item.dc:creator: Peter Baker
item.media:description: President Biden visited President Volodymyr Zelensky in Kyiv last week as support for the Ukrainian war effort in the United States has shifted.

item.title: Ukraine Reinforces Embattled Bakhmut, but Mission Is Unclear
item.description: Amid persistent rumors of Ukrainian withdrawal from the war’s most prolonged battle, officials said nothing about the size or purpose of the reinforcement.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Mpoke Bigg and Edward Wong
item.media:description: Ukrainian troops in the area of Bakhmut, in the Donbas region of eastern Ukraine, on Tuesday. The battle for the city has caused both sides devastating losses.

item.title: Hundreds of Schoolgirls Fall Sick in Iran, and Officials Suspect Poisoning
item.description: Girls have been hospitalized in over 10 cities with respiratory, cardiac and neurological symptoms. Senior officials said they might have been poisoned.
item.dc:creator: Farnaz Fassihi
item.media:description: Iranian girls attending class at a private high school north of Tehran in 2020.

item.title: U.S. Braces for G20 Clash Over Ukraine War
item.description: China is urging the start of peace talks and could raise that among the Group of 20 nations in India, but U.S. officials argue Russia would not negotiate in good faith.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.media:description: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken boarding his plane in Tashkent, Uzbekistan, on Wednesday,

item.title: Unionists in Northern Ireland Face Dilemma Over New Trade Deal
item.description: The Democratic Unionist Party has no legal power to hold up the agreement, which would simplify post-Brexit trade rules. But a rejection could sabotage efforts to restart Northern Ireland’s government.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler

item.title: Maurizio Costanzo, Who Transformed Italian Talk Shows, Dies at 84
item.description: Praised by critics as the inventor of contemporary Italian television, he also used his position to take on the Sicilian Mafia, which tried to kill him.
item.dc:creator: Gaia Pianigiani
item.media:description: Maurizio Costanzo in 1995 on the stage of his talk show, where he interviewed politicians, actors, singers and celebrities.

item.title: Your Thursday Briefing: Nigeria’s New ‘Big Boss’
item.description: Also, a major tank battle in Ukraine and a deadly train wreck in Greece.
item.dc:creator: Mariah Kreutter and Daniel E. Slotnik
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas
item.media:description: Bola Tinubu celebrating with supporters at his party’s campaign headquarters after winning the presidential elections in Abuja, Nigeria, on Wednesday.

item.title: Finland on Cusp of Joining NATO, but Maybe Not With Sweden
item.description: The Nordic partners wanted to join together, but with Turkey holding up Sweden’s application, Helsinki will reluctantly enter alone to ensure its security.
item.dc:creator: Steven Erlanger and Andrew Higgins
item.media:description: The vote by Finland’s Parliament on Wednesday is subject to ratification by the Parliaments of Turkey and Hungary.

item.title: Turkey’s Earthquake Will Not Delay Elections in Country, Erdogan Says
item.description: The Feb. 6 earthquake’s vast destruction will present a challenge when it comes to mounting a viable election. But President Recep Tayyip Erdogan said the vote would go on in May, “God willing.”
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Gulsin Harman
item.media:description: President Recep Tayyip Erdogan of Turkey speaking on Wednesday during a party meeting in Turkey’s capital, Ankara.

item.title: Bola Tinubu Elected to Be Nigeria’s Next President
item.description: Bola Tinubu, declared the winner on Wednesday in the presidential election, has boasted of making the careers of major politicians. Now he has to deliver for a divided country facing multiple emergencies.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean and Elian Peltier
item.media:description: Bola Tinubu celebrating with supporters at his party’s campaign headquarters after winning the presidential elections in Abuja, Nigeria, on Wednesday.

item.title: Peter Obi, Third-Party Candidate in Nigeria Election, Refuses to Concede
item.description: Peter Obi was until recently a secondary player in Nigerian politics. By switching parties and appealing to the digitally savvy, he overturned the old order.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Taiwo Aina for The New York Times
item.media:description: Peter Obi campaigning in Lagos, Nigeria’s largest city, on Feb. 11.

item.title: Israeli Police Use Stun Grenades on Protesters in Tel Aviv
item.description: The confrontations escalated tensions between the political leadership and protesters opposed to the far-right government’s plan to curb the powers of the judiciary.
item.dc:creator: Isabel Kershner
item.media:description: Police officers hold back demonstrators blocking a road in the city center during an antigovernment protest in Tel Aviv on Wednesday. Several protesters were arrested or injured.

item.title: Eritrea Faces Growing Scrutiny for Role in Ethiopia’s War in Tigray
item.description: Eritrean troops have been accused of war crimes in the northern Tigray region just weeks before a peace agreement was signed last year.
item.dc:creator: Abdi Latif Dahir and Simon Marks
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:description: A satellite image showing military equipment positioned in the village of Serha in Eritrea, across the border from the town of Zalambessa in the Tigray region of northern Ethiopia in September.

item.title: Foreign Adversaries ‘Very Unlikely’ to Blame for Havana Syndrome, Intelligence Review Finds
item.description: The assessment concluded that there was no credible evidence that any adversaries had developed a weapon capable of causing the injuries that U.S. officials have reported.
item.dc:creator: Julian E. Barnes and Adam Entous
item.media:description: The U.S. Embassy in Havana, where the first reports of the mysterious ailments emerged. Some victims believe the episodes were caused by a foreign power.
